info.game_comments:
1998 Teen Reunion Tournament preliminary game 4.
From the Wang Center for the Performing Arts in Boston, Massachusetts.

(1, 1).clue: In 1959 he was president of the Screen Actors Guild; 10 years later he was governor of California

(2, 1).clue: Born on a farm in Dearborn, Michigan in 1863, he repaired steam engines before building cars

(3, 1).clue: Liv Tyler co-starred in "Armageddon", which featured this Boston band, her dad's, on the soundtrack

(4, 1).clue: Footage from Iceland & Switzerland was used on "Nova"'s show about this title natural disaster

(5, 1).clue: "Sponsor" is another term for this; Don Vito Corleone was Johnny Fontane's sponsor

(6, 1).clue: Ecuador is the world's largest exporter of this fruit's Cavendish species

(1, 2).clue: In 1910 there were 46 U.S. states; 10 years later there were this many

(2, 2).clue: In 1998 "Profiles In History" offered for sale this Wild West doc's dental kit, seen here

(3, 2).clue: The Mighty Mighty Bosstones gained mighty good exposure after appearing in this Alicia Silverstone film

(4, 2).clue: This dinosaur's skeleton was discovered in Montana

(5, 2).clue: Georgia & Alabama are among states recognizing this type of marriage without ceremony, based on cohabitation

(6, 2).clue: "Hats Off" to this country's president Ernesto Perez Balladares

(1, 3).clue: In the '82-'83 season, "60 Minutes" was the No. 1 rated TV show in the U.S.; 10 years later, this was No. 1

(2, 3).clue: John C. Fremont, who hadn't heard of this scout before hiring him, later wrote tales of his exploits

(3, 3).clue: The younger brother of New Kid Donnie, he had "Good Vibrations" with the Funky Bunch

(4, 3).clue: In 1998 "Nova" trekked up this mountain to study the effects of oxygen deprivation

(5, 3).clue: This married couple, seen here, became a symbol of the idealized family of the 1950s

(6, 3).clue: From Spanish for hut, it's a little shelter that opens onto a swimming pool

(1, 4).clue: In 1978 Bob Griese was the starting quarterback for the Dolphins; 10 years later it was this man

(2, 4).clue: (VIDEO DAILY DOUBLE):He was called Armstrong, or "Offie", as a child

(3, 4).clue: Peter Wolf was a DJ for Boston's WBCN before joining this "Freeze-Frame" band as its singer

(4, 4).clue: Mission Control played the song "I Can See Clearly Now" for the astronauts who fixed this object

(5, 4).clue: These kits were introduced for home use in the '70s; they didn't come with a rabbit

(6, 4).clue: Among Cendant Corporation's hotel chains are Days Inn, Howard Johnson & this inn

(1, 5).clue: In 1810 Napoleon was at the height of his power; 10 years later he was on this island

(2, 5).clue: After the Civil War this vice president of the Confederacy served in the U.S. Congress

(3, 5).clue: Aimee Mann of this "Voices Carry" band attended the Berklee School of Music

(4, 5).clue: The actions of this type of ant show how it got its name

(5, 5).clue: Samuel Johnson described this type of event as "The triumph of hope over experience"

(1, 1).clue: Gore Vidal's play about this president opened & closed a few weeks before the Watergate break-in

(2, 1).clue: By 1965 this teenage Austrian was so muscular he was named Junior Mr. Europe

(3, 1).clue: This former senator & Conservative icon from Arizona passed away in 1998 at age 89

(4, 1).clue: His theory of evolution is widely accepted; his son George's theory of the moon's origin isn't

(5, 1).clue: Patricio Guzman chronicled Salvador Allende's overthrow in "The Battle Of" this country

(1, 2).clue: He had a play on Broadway called "The Traitor" in 1949, 2 years before his novel "The Caine Mutiny" appeared

(2, 2).clue: This star of "A Time To Kill" was voted the handsomest guy at Longview High; you might want to "Contact" him

(3, 2).clue: Alaska's second most populous city is named for this man who was vice president under Teddy Roosevelt

(4, 2).clue: Karen Horney critiqued the biologically-based theory of this founder of psychoanalysis

(6, 2).clue: Heavyweight champ Larry & golfing champ Tom

(1, 3).clue: In 1908 this "Of Human Bondage" author had 4 of his plays running in London at the same time

(2, 3).clue: Meryl Streep played Laurey in her high school production of this Rodgers & Hammerstein musical

(3, 3).clue: Between 1811 & 1852 this Kentuckian served in the House, the Senate & as Secretary of State

(6, 3).clue: Jekyll's dark half & a worshipper at the Golden Temple in the Punjab

(1, 4).clue: His first play, "The Silver Box", premiered in 1906, the same year he published Book I of "The Forsyte Saga"

(2, 4).clue: Seen here as a youth, this son of a senator was captain of the football team at St. Alban's in Washington, D.C.

(3, 4).clue: In 1996 he published a very personal account of his daughter Terry's "Life And Death Struggle With Alcoholism"

(5, 4).clue: Type of graveyard that's the subject of the documentary "Gates Of Heaven" & of a Stephen King book

(6, 4).clue: A WWII German defensive line & Judge Bean

(1, 5).clue: This play by Agatha Christie that opened in 1952 is still running; they'll never build a better one

(2, 5).clue: In the '40s this Supreme Court justice was a cute cheerleader at her high school in Brooklyn

(3, 5).clue: This Texan served in the house for 25 consecutive terms & was Speaker of the House 3 times

(5, 5).clue: Jean Rouch's 1961 "Chronicle Of A Summer" originated this style, French for "film truth"

(6, 5).clue: "The Magic Mountain" author & a 1978 Christopher Reeve role

(0, 0).clue: Plans are for steel cables to temporarily replace the over 800 tons of lead that counterbalance it
